description: From Ancient Greek μόνος (mónos, “alone, solitary; mono-”) +‎ οἶκος (oîkos, “house, dwelling-place”).

entries.meaning: (botany, invertebrate) Having both the male and female reproductive organs in the same individual, either in different flowers or in the same or different flowers; hermaphrodite.
examples: Further, species which show continuous variation that is not amenable to orthodox taxonomic treatment, and this is the situation in many monoecious plants, are treated as invariable.
